metadata.case_name: Union of India v. N.K. Pvt. Ltd.

facts.text: On 21st March 1968, notice of Global Tender No. 1 of 1968 issued by President of India, Ministry of Railways, Railway Board, proposing to sell 80,000 tonnes of surplus released serviceable and scrap rails to established buyers abroad or their accredited agents.

Tender notice enclosed general conditions of tender, special conditions, instructions to tenderers including proforma for performance guarantee and deed bonds (clauses 4A and 4B), shipping terms, schedule of stocks as on 1st March 1968.
Seller defined as President of India acting through Director, Railway Stores, Railway Board. Clause 11 default clause empowered Director to declare contract at end at buyer's risk and cost.

Instructions to tenderers required offers addressed to President of India, sent to Director, Railway Stores. Tenderer to confirm clauses or indicate deviations. Contract to come into force from date buyer's letter of credit accepted by seller's nominee.
Respondents by letter Ex. B dated 21-5-1968 offered to buy 80,000 tonnes at 45.1 per tonne F.O.B. Indian Ports on terms and conditions set out therein.
Dy. Director P.C. Oak by letter dated 25-5-1968 requested respondents to clarify shipping terms, confirm offer addressed to President of India, reply by 28-5-1968.
No reply received by 28-5-1968. Letter dated 3-6-1968 by C. Parasuraman for Secretary, Railway Board seeking clarification on items 26 and 27, weight of tonne, option to transfer contract.
Respondents wrote letters on 15th June, 29th June, 8th July, three on 10th July, one on 15th July 1968, some after discussions with Director of Railway Stores and Director of Finance Mr. Datta.

P.C. Oak for Secretary, Railway Board by letter No. 68/RS G /709/10 dated 15-7-1968 accepted respondents' offer at 39 per long ton F.O.B. Indian Port for export and Rs. 458/- per long ton for indigenous consumption with terms in above letters. Formal contract to be issued shortly.

Several draft agreements exchanged. Draft agreement (5th draft per appellants, final per respondents) handed to respondents by P.C. Oak on 27-8-1968, not signed. Clause 2 stated contract concluded by letter dated 15-7-1968, term 3 years from 1-11-1968 to 31-10-1971.
Respondents letter dated 18-9-1968 agreed to several matters for final draft, requested issue of final contract.
Respondents letter dated 21-9-1968 complained information from Railways incomplete.
Joint Director, Railway Stores wrote to General Managers, All Indian Railways stating Board finalized export-cum-internal sale contract with M/s N.K. Pvt. Ltd. for 3 years.
C. Parasuraman for Secretary replied 23-10-1968 denying assurance for missing details.

Respondents letters dated 7-11-1968 and 23-11-1968: Stated contract concluded 15-7-1968, draft handed 27-8-1968, approved 53,807 tonnes, requested reservation and delivery; complained no formal contract issued, stop sales by Railways.

P.C. Oak for Secretary replied that letter 15-7-1968 indicated intention only, no agreement reached on vital terms post discussions on 20-7-68, 12-8-68, 26-8-68, 27-8-68, culminating in 18-9-68 letter; no concluded contract.
Respondents letter dated 25-1-1969 contested stand.
Respondents filed application under Sec 20 Arbitration Act. Single Judge directed appellants to file arbitration agreement. Division Bench dismissed appeal.
Appellants' written statement: No arbitration agreement, letter 15-7-68 not acceptance, no concluded contract; Art 299 not complied with.
Application dated 7-2-72 with affidavits of R.N. Mubayi (Director 1965-1969) and R.B. Lal (MD respondent No.1) filed evening before judgment.
File perused: Endorsement by Oak on 15-7-68 referenced Board's orders, Mubayi signed but no initials on draft letter approving it.
Affidavit of R. Srinivasan: Secretary Railway Board had no status of Director under Para XLI on 15-7-68.

legal_issues.text: Whether there is a binding, valid and concluded contract between the appellants and the respondents.
Whether the mandatory requirements of Article 299 of the Constitution have been satisfied for a valid contract binding on the Union of India.

petitioner_arguments.text: No concluded contract because essential terms not agreed on 15-7-68, acceptance conditional on formal contract execution.
Article 299 not complied with: Contract not expressed in name of President, not executed on his behalf by authorized person.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 299 of the Constitution of India

petitioner_arguments.text: Secretary, Railway Board not authorized; only Director, Railway Stores authorized per tender terms and notifications.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Notifications under Article 299; Clauses 9, 43 Part XVIII, Part XLI

respondent_arguments.text: Letter dated 15-7-1968 was definite acceptance constituting binding contract; further negotiations on non-essential terms.
Secretary, Railway Board authorized via clauses 43 Part XVIII, Part XLI; or as Director/Joint Secretary.
Director Mubayi instructed Oak to convey acceptance.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide if concluded contract existed apart from Art 299; focus on authorization.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Secretary to Railway Board not authorized to enter contract on behalf of President.

court_reasoning.text: Tender invited offers to President through Director, Railway Stores; seller through Director; default by Director.
Clause 9 covers contracts for scrap/stores including relayable rails; Clause 43 not applicable.
Part XLI requires Secretary to Central Government in Ministry, not Secretary to Railway Board.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Secretary Railway Board not having required status till 15-9-1969.

court_reasoning.text: File shows acceptance per Board's orders, not Director's; no proof Secretary was Director.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Additional evidence does not establish authorization.

holdings.text: No valid or binding contract as letter of acceptance not by person authorized to execute contracts for President of India.
Contract by tender and acceptance possible if by authorized person, but here not.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seth Bikhraj Jaipuria v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Authority to execute contracts may be conferred specifically even ad hoc, apart from notifications.

statutes_cited.name: Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Application filed by respondents to direct filing of arbitration agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Mandatory requirements for valid contract binding on Union: expressed in name of President, executed by authorized person.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave allowed. Application under Section 20 of Arbitration Act dismissed as no valid arbitration agreement due to no binding contract.
outcome.costs: No order as to costs of the appellants.

key_quotes.text: "The crucial question which arises for determination is whether there was a concluded contract, and if there was one, whether the mandatory requirements of Article 299 of the Constitution for entering into a valid and binding contract have been satisfied?"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A contract whether by a formal deed or otherwise by persons not authorized by the President cannot be binding and is absolutely void."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains consequence of non-compliance with Art 299.

key_quotes.text: "there is no valid or binding contract because the letter of acceptance, on the evidence before us, is not by a person authorized to execute the contracts for and on behalf of the President of India."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key holding on lack of authorization.
